title: Man who went ‘rampage’ with shotgun ‘tried to murder two police officers’
text:
Daniel Hannam denies trying to murder two police officers and kidnap Mr Walter-Taylor (Picture: PA)

A man who ran riot with a shotgun around a Somerset town fired at two armed police officers in an attempt to murder them, a court heard.

Daniel Hannam, 32 took the ‘unlawfully obtained’ firearm and cartridges to the streets of Castle Carry on January 23.

The jury heard how he blasted the gun multiple times in different locations and used it to try and kidnap a man before returning to his girlfriend’s house.

Police surrounded the property at 2.45am on January 23, after fearful members of the public dialed 999.

David Scutt, prosecuting, told Bristol Crown Court: ‘Realising he was surrounded and desperate, he deliberately fired at armed police officers intending to kill them as they tried to gain entry to that house.

Pictures of the ‘unlawfully obtained’ shotgun was shown to the jury (Picture: PA)

Pellet marks were left in a car after Hannam allegedly let off shots (Picture: PA)

‘They were at the front door of the house and the defendant went to the front bedroom.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘He opened that window and he fired down onto the officers outside.’

Hannam is accused of attempting to murder two officers, referred to as IX and IC, who twice approached the door.

Bodycam footage played to the jury showed armed police outside the property, with the sound of a helicopter overhead.

The officers shout ‘armed police’ and ‘put that down now’ before ‘shots fired’ and ‘get back, get back’.

One of them is seen firing back at the upstairs window, shouting ‘Yes I fired’.

Bodycam footage shows the terrifying police siege in Castle Carry, Somerset (Picture: PA)

Hannam admits possessing a firearm with intent to cause fear of violence (Picture: PA)

They then move back behind an armed response vehicle parked nearby.

In police interview, Hannam said he had gone to see his on-off girlfriend in Park Street and had taken his shotgun and some cartridges with him to meet a man he had previously argued with.

While waiting for him, he fired the gun into the air before returning to the house.

Hannam then left to buy cocaine but could not get hold of his supplier, which made him ‘very cross’, Mr Scutt said.

He went to McColls newsagents for alcohol and cigarettes, shooting twice at the door, before walking to a nearby car park at 1.44am.

Advertisement

Advertisement

The court heard how minutes later, Hannam approached the car of Oliver Walter-Taylor, who had driven there to meet a friend.

He then tried to kidnap him by getting into his BMW while holding the gun, the jury was told.

Mr Scutt said Hannam fired two shots ‘apparently into the air’, with pellets hitting the car.

The defendant allegedly fired the shotgun into the air while he was waiting for someone he previously had an argument with (Picture: PA)

Neither of the two armed police officers were harmed (Picture: PA)

In a call to 999, Mr Walter Taylor said: ‘Someone has just pointed a shotgun at me.

‘He has just fired another shot. I’ve just legged it.’

Mr Scutt told the jury that Hannam’s actions could be described as a ‘rampage’.

Hannam later told police that his girlfriend had woken him up to tell him that armed police were outside.

The court heard how he kept on firing until he ran out of cartridges, before throwing the shotgun out of the back window and surrendering to police.

Neither IX or IC were hit by the shot or shots fired out the front window.

The side of the armed response vehicle that officers ‘scrambled for cover’ behind was hit, Mr Scutt said.

Hannam denies two counts of attempting to murder a police officer, possessing a firearm with intent to endanger life and attempting to kidnap Mr Walter-Taylor.

Advertisement

He has admitted possessing a firearm with intent to cause fear of violence, making use of a firearm with intent to resist arrest and attempting to burgle the McColls shop.

The trial continues.

description: Bristol Crown Court heard how Daniel Hannam fired a shotgun at armed police after going on a 'rampage' in Castle Carry, Somerset.
